awd_titl_txt: CS10K: C-START: Colorado - STrategic Approach to Rally Teachers
awd_abstract_narration:
The Colorado School of Mines (CSM), in partnership with the University of Northern Colorado (UNC), proposes a project to improve the skills of existing computer science (CS) teachers, share best practices in CS pedagogy, and positively change the diversity of students in existing and new CS courses in Colorado.  The project -- called C-START (Colorado: STrategic Approach to Rally Teachers) -- will create high-quality professional development (PD) opportunities, empower, and support more than 50 high school teachers, enabling them to teach a progression of CS courses, from the introductory level through Advanced Placement® (AP) CS. These opportunities will leverage recent efforts for K-12 CS PD and best practices in broadening participation in computing developed by the BPC-A Alliances and other NSF Broadening Participation in Computing projects. 

More specifically, C-START will: 

-- Create two academic certificates for CS teachers at the College of Education and Behavioral Sciences at UNC,
-- Incorporate computational thinking skills into the educational technologies requirement at UNC, 
-- Re-energize the only CSTA Chapter in Colorado, 
-- Introduce an undergraduate Service Learning course at CSM that will engage students in K-12 CS education, and 
-- Develop a tiered mentoring program for high school teachers who teach CS.

The effectiveness of C-START's approach will be measured by teacher outcomes: Does engaging in C-START have a positive impact on high school teachers' CS content knowledge, confidence that they can teach CS, attitudes toward CS, and knowledge in engaging underrepresented students in CS?  Lastly, C-START will be sustainable, in order to ensure the PD opportunities and planned support for teachers will continue after the grant period ends.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the C-START project was to support the national CS10K program goals within the state of Colorado by facilitating more and better computer science (CS) education opportunities for high school students. Specific objectives included significantly increasing the number of teachers in Colorado who can offer rigorous CS courses in high schools, improving the skills of existing CS teachers (e.g., by sharing best practices in CS pedagogy and recruiting diverse students to classes), and positively changing the diversity of students within both current and new CS courses. 

In our original proposal, we expected that 36-54 Colorado high school teachers would benefit from our trainings due to this grant. We have immensely surpassed our expectations. Specifically, CSTART has provided summer professional development courses to 1,506 teachers. 

In 2014, the year before this grant began, only 170 high school students took the AP Computer Science A exam (the CS Principles was not yet available) and only 15.4% of those students were female. In 2021, 2,700 high school students took an AP Computer Science exam in Colorado (923 took the AP CS A exam and 1,777 took the AP CSP exam). Furthermore, 21.4% of the AP CS A exam takers were female and 29.2% of the AP CSP exam takers were female in 2020. In addition, in 2014, only 2.2% (7.3%) of the AP CS exam takers in Colorado were Black (Hispanic/Latino), while in 2020, 2.3% (14.4%) of the AP CS exam takers in Colorado were Black (Hispanic/Latino); we note Colorado high schools have many more Hispanic/Latino students than Black/African American students. While C-START is not the only professional development opportunity for Colorado teachers, we are confident C-START had a significant positive impact in Colorado computer science high school education. Our C-START professional development program has provided an essential service for CS education in Colorado.

Colorado still has work to do. According to the 2021 State of the States Report by the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) and Code.org, 51% of all high schools offer a CS course in the United States while only 42% of high schools in Colorado offer a CS course. Also, we are behind the nation in terms of underrepresented students in computing taking an AP Computer Science exam, e.g., 25.0% (33.9%) of AP CS A (CSP) exam takers were female nationwide in 2020. To continue the work, 12 district leaders across Colorado, from 12 different districts of varying size/demographics, are working together to continue the forward progress that this grant began. 

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2023
Modified by: Tracy K Camp
